sub_topic: Identifying the Eulerian and Hamiltonian paths in a graph.
message_1:
Consider the graph below:

![Graph theory](https://i.imgur.com/bszmdZa.png)

(i) Identify whether the graph has an Eulerian path or Eulerian circuit, and if yes, provide the order in which the edges must be traversed to form the Eulerian path/circuit.

(ii) Identify whether the graph has a Hamiltonian path or Hamiltonian circuit, and if yes, provide the order in which the vertices must be traversed to form the Hamiltonian path/circuit.
message_2:
(i) To determine if the graph has an Eulerian path or Eulerian circuit, we need to check the degrees of the vertices. A graph has an Eulerian circuit if all vertices have even degrees, and it has an Eulerian path if exactly two vertices have odd degrees.

In this graph, the degrees of the vertices are:
A: 3
B: 3
C: 4
D: 3
E: 3

Since there are four vertices with odd degrees (A, B, D, and E), the graph does not have an Eulerian circuit. However, since there are exactly two vertices with odd degrees (A and E), the graph has an Eulerian path.

One possible Eulerian path is: A-B-C-D-E-C-B-D-A-E.

(ii) To determine if the graph has a Hamiltonian path or Hamiltonian circuit, we need to find a path or circuit that visits each vertex exactly once.

In this graph, there is a Hamiltonian path: A-B-C-D-E.

However, there is no Hamiltonian circuit, as there is no way to return to the starting vertex (A) without visiting another vertex more than once.
